2.74.text:
[applause]
Tyler Cowen:  Camille has written the very

4.00.text:
best essays ever on Edmund Spenser, "Alice
in Wonderland..."

8.98.text:
Camille Paglia:  [laughs]
Tyler:  ...and the Marquis de Sade. She understands

12.07.text:
Bob Dylan and Susan Sontag...
Camille:  [hisses]

15.20.text:
Tyler:  ...and she has pursued a career of
great integrity. That's my introduction for

21.90.text:
Tyler:  I'd like to start with a question
from a reader. I asked readers for questions.

25.53.text:
"How do you feel about the fact that Silicon
Valley dominates our economy and culture?

30.55.text:
Is there any tech guru you're interested in?"
Camille:  No. My last big tech guru was probably

37.11.text:
Marshall McLuhan. Had a prophetic insight
into what was about to happen. He's kind of

41.59.text:
the patron saint of my working on the web
from the very first issue of "Salon" in 1995.

50.71.text:
It's hard to believe that the web wasn't taken
seriously by already‑established journalists.

58.44.text:
There was a major political reporter at "The
Boston Globe," for example, who tried to pressure

64.04.text:
me not to write for the web. He said, "Oh,
no one takes the web seriously." It's an enormous

69.22.text:
thing that's happened. Which, of course, has
also sucked in a whole generation of young

73.35.text:
people, alas. That's all they know. I think
we're kind of on the down side of that right

78.22.text:
now.
Tyler:  Take your last book, "Glittering

81.42.text:
Images," and your other work, which emphasized
the role of the iconic in Western and Eastern

86.42.text:
culture, the role of the spectacular. Vivid
visual life‑giving spectacular events. Now

93.31.text:
here we have people, they look, they listen
on very small smartphones. Is this culture

98.11.text:
dead? But if the culture was so splendid,
why did people give it up so quickly?

101.85.text:
Camille:  The reason I wrote Glittering Images
is because I felt that there's an avalanche

107.82.text:
of fragmented visual impressions ‑‑ disconnected,
glaring, tacky, badly designed ‑‑ that

115.92.text:
young people are growing up in. I think it
really is true that children's brains are

121.19.text:
being reshaped. The standard forms for logic
and for sequential information and for reasoning,

130.86.text:
everything's kind of disappearing. I tried
to write a book where people would just stare

134.86.text:
at an image for a certain length of time.
I think it's getting worse and worse. Web

138.28.text:
design, which my school, University of the
Arts, teaches ‑‑ I think web design is

142.64.text:
in the pits. I thought web design was moving
into a major genre of the arts. I think we're

149.62.text:
in a kind of swirling vortex, and yes, what
you mentioned about the miniaturization of

154.47.text:
image is terrible.
I was raised in a time ‑‑ 1950s ‑‑ when

158.47.text:
Hollywood was competing with television by
doing something which television couldn't

162.00.text:
do, those gigantic screens. Like "The Ten
Commandments," there's a giant thing of Pharaoh,

168.46.text:
a giant sculpture. It starts at one end of
the screen and you watch it go to the other

172.43.text:
end of the screen. Phenomenal. "Lawrence of
Arabia," oh my God, the dunes of Lawrence

176.51.text:
of Arabia with that music.
There's no sense of the large. Young people

180.45.text:
have no sense whatever of the expansive, of
the big gesture.

183.38.text:
Tyler:  But do we maybe overrate the large?
If the large gave through so quickly, so readily,

188.21.text:
to what you're describing as this kind of
mediocrity, what was wrong with that culture

192.82.text:
of the '50s, '60s, and '70s to begin with?
Camille:  I would say that a culture always

196.56.text:
moves in cycles. You have periods that esteem
the colossal, like the Bernini Renaissance

206.72.text:
and Baroque periods. Then you get the small,
the art of the small. The Rococo is a kind

214.63.text:
of evanescence, evaporation of the big Baroque
swirls. All of a sudden it's little tiny things

221.90.text:
like on a Valentine's card.
I think we go back and forth. I just feel

225.42.text:
lucky, I think, that I have a kind of epic
imagination, because I was raised watching

231.44.text:
The Ten Commandments and "Ben‑Hur." Oh my
God, Ben‑Hur. I could watch that 300 times.

236.76.text:
Tyler:  One of your 10 favorite movies, right?
Camille:  Yeah.

239.03.text:
Tyler:  It's the one on the list that's surprising.
[laughter]

241.19.text:
Camille:  Torment. The music, and the music
composed for those things. It directly inspired

246.98.text:
my writing of "Sexual Personae," absolutely.
I'm directly inspired by music. I think for

251.34.text:
women's it's good to have something that's
going to make you assert and trample, [laughs]

255.61.text:
and conquer. It animates me. These are my
maxims.

261.30.text:
Tyler:  Given what you're saying, do you
today consider yourself a cultural conservative?

267.28.text:
Camille:  No, not at all.
Tyler:  Why not? Everything used to be better.

274.65.text:
Camille:  No, we're in a period of decadence,
a falling‑off, you see. No, conservative

281.20.text:
would mean that I would be cleaving to something
past which was great, and no longer is, and

290.48.text:
I would be saying, "We need to return to that."
Usually I'm not saying we need to return to

294.73.text:
anything. I do believe we're moving inexorably
into the future. There's a momentum to that.

300.37.text:
I'm a libertarian. That's why I'm always freely
offending both sides.

308.07.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Liberal, conservative. I'm a Democrat,

311.00.text:
even though I'm constantly criticizing...I
think a true intellectual should be always

317.42.text:
beyond partisanship.
Tyler:  And always criticizing.

319.56.text:
Camille:  Yes, and always critiquing the
premises of your own friends and allies.

325.02.text:
Tyler:  In the back, we were talking about
Brazil. You mentioned you've been there nine

330.29.text:
Tyler:  What does Brazilian culture have
which North American culture lacks? What's

334.94.text:
the draw?
Camille:  It's such a polyglot of cultures

338.81.text:
and ethnicities. But beyond that, Brazilians
understood my work from the first moment I

344.03.text:
began to publish. Because what they understood
was artifice, art ‑‑ because of Carnival

350.62.text:
for them, and costuming, masquerade, and that
Baroque exuberance, and the syncretism of

358.07.text:
Christianity with the Yoruba cults of West
Africa in Salvador de Bahia.

362.24.text:
They understood my vision of art, and beauty,
and beauty as an incredibly important human

370.84.text:
principle, rather than the way it was being
trashed by my fellow feminists at that time.

375.28.text:
They also understand nature, the grandeur
of nature, the power of nature.

378.84.text:
Tyler:  [inaudible 10:10] too, right?
Camille:  Yes, instead of these silly little

382.36.text:
arguments that, "Oh, climate change is causing
the end of the world." Oh my God. Anyone who

386.21.text:
talks like that does not understand the grandeur
and the power of nature. To imagine that we

390.76.text:
can make a change in it is so absolutely absurd.
Tyler:  What's your theory of modernity that

394.97.text:
puts them on one part of the curve, and we're
on another, more decadent part of the curve?

400.25.text:
What's the difference? What's what we would
call the structural equilibrium as economists,

403.72.text:
if I dare invoke such a thing?
Camille:  Brazil, it's in its own world.

409.25.text:
It's not been part of the world wars. It doesn't
have this huge militaristic superstructure.

415.90.text:
It doesn't have a messianic view of itself
politically. The politics are always chaos

421.80.text:
[laughs] and drama. It's like in grand opera.
It's like another planet, really, Brazil.

430.49.text:
Tyler:  To continue the whirlwind tour of
Camille Paglia, you wrote in Glittering Images

436.05.text:
that George Lucas was perhaps, or maybe definitely,
the greatest artist of our time. I do not

441.76.text:
disagree with that, but now that you've written
that, "The Force Awakens" has come out, which

447.59.text:
is not George Lucas. It's Disney, who is not
the greatest artist of our time.

451.58.text:
Camille:  It has nothing to do with George
Lucas, and...

452.58.text:
Tyler:  What did you think?
Camille:  ...I haven't seen it. When it's

454.92.text:
on TV, I'll look at it. Please. Do you think
I want to sit in a theater and be tortured

461.59.text:
by the contamination of my ideals? I'm not
going to do that.

466.48.text:
[laughter]
Tyler:  You've spoken very highly of the

469.13.text:
prequels, which many people don't like at
all.

471.14.text:
Camille:  Yes.
Tyler:  What is it that people don't get

472.80.text:
about the prequels? They say Jar Jar Binks,
and they scream, and they run away...

476.47.text:
Camille:  I can't tell you.
Tyler:  ...clutching their head.

478.34.text:
Camille:  I know exactly what they're talking
about.

479.92.text:
Tyler:  Tell us what's good about the sequels.
Camille:  It was "Revenge of the Sith," after

483.67.text:
the great volcano planet climax of Revenge
of the Sith. I think it's one of the greatest

488.45.text:
sequences in all of modern art. The thing
is once I had written about it, I realized,

493.35.text:
as I went out in the world, how few people
had actually seen the movie, because people

497.25.text:
had given up on the prequels long before.
Therefore, I think anyone who dismisses what

502.17.text:
I say about the sublime quality, the vision,
the execution, the emotions, and the passions

508.77.text:
of that scene, they don't know what I'm talking
about, because they haven't exposed themselves

515.37.text:
Tyler:  Music. Rolling Stones. There are
the two albums, Hot Rocks, More Hot Rocks.

521.23.text:
You wrote about the Rolling Stones some time
ago, but if I look at the career of the Stones

525.37.text:
‑‑ they have a new album coming out this
year ‑‑ I find it striking that they've

528.71.text:
kept on going. I actually count that as a
mark against them.

533.18.text:
I still think they're good, but when I go
back and listen, I never hear new things in

537.90.text:
their music. Now that some time has passed,
what would you say about the Rolling Stones,

542.67.text:
and do you agree that you're a little disappointed
with them?

545.01.text:
Camille:  I haven't been following them for
many, many years. To me, the Rolling Stones

550.53.text:
were a revolution when they happened, in that
period when the Beatles were all upbeat. Then,

555.34.text:
here come these surly guys sneering, and spitting,
and so on.

558.22.text:
Tyler:  The Beatles were dark and subtle,
too, right?

560.58.text:
Camille:  Not like the Stones. Here's the
difference. The Rolling Stones are inspired

565.68.text:
by, animated by, to this day, by the blues
tradition. The Beatles really were more almost

574.96.text:
Broadway and musical comedy.
Tyler:  British music hall.

577.68.text:
Camille:  Yes, British music hall, and Tin
Pan Alley, and so on. They were tremendous

581.46.text:
songsmiths, but there's nothing dark about
them. In other words, Paul McCartney was a

586.98.text:
wonderful bass player, but you're not getting
the big, roaring sounds of Bill Wyman's bass

592.19.text:
at the beginning of the Stones' career.
I really have not been following the Stones.

598.11.text:
Ever since Bill Wyman left the Stones, I have
not felt that this were the Stones I knew.

603.57.text:
I'm delighted that they go on, and that they
perform, and so on, but I have absolutely

607.36.text:
no interest in exposing myself to those horrible
arena conditions for music. Oh my goodness,

616.33.text:
just the light shows and the this and the
that. They're not musical experiences. They're

623.10.text:
social experiences now.
Tyler:  What's the music from classic rock

626.01.text:
that when you listen to it today, every single
time you hear more in it? I would say Brian

630.61.text:
Wilson and Jimi Hendrix. Every time I hear
them, it sounds different and fresher for

634.97.text:
me. What are your picks?
Camille:  Jimi Hendrix is one of the great

639.07.text:
geniuses of any instrument in the last a hundred
years. Obviously, his music has lasted and

645.13.text:
is still fresh. For me, there's a whole period
there I teach in my Art of Song Lyrics course.

652.25.text:
I just was doing Crosby, Stills & Nash "Wooden
Ships," and it still has this incredible power.

661.41.text:
I love that entire period of the 1960s, the
music. It was a magic moment. Still in the

668.28.text:
'70s, Led Zeppelin, "When the Levy Breaks."
It still has enormous power, a lot of that

673.80.text:
music that Jimmy Page was doing. A lot of
it working in the studio, actually. It wasn't

679.98.text:
Tyler:  Fast‑forward back to the present.
Who would be a musical artist today...I know

684.62.text:
you've written Taylor Swift as a pestilence,
so it's probably not her.

687.98.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Taylor Swift is like a nightmare.

689.13.text:
Tyler:  Who would be the musical artist today
who stands up to the giants of the past?

694.58.text:
Camille:  Stands up working today?
Tyler:  Working today or close to today.

698.95.text:
The last 10 years.
Camille:  I was really very hopeful about

702.10.text:
Rihanna for a while there. Unfortunately,
she's not really working with the top producers

708.26.text:
any longer. The new album is an atrocity.
It's really terrible. It's sad, because there

715.16.text:
are so many people with talents who are not
being developed.

717.98.text:
It's because our music industry is now very
formulaic. Young people can't really move

725.09.text:
along studying their instruments and getting
their chops over a period of time. There's

732.32.text:
nothing to draw on in the way that the musicians
of my generation could draw on the folk tradition,

738.28.text:
the folk music.
Tyler:  You're sounding like a cultural conservative.

741.27.text:
[laughs]
Camille:  I'm just saying there's certain

743.72.text:
moments, certain magic moments, of fertility
or creativity that happened in many of the

751.31.text:
arts. You can find certain key moments where
there's a confluence of influences and a certain

755.56.text:
richness. In that very moment, it's a great
time to be alive, to be young.

758.46.text:
For example, Shakespeare would not be Shakespeare
if he were alive today. As it happens, he

762.80.text:
left Stratford for whatever reason, went to
London at a magic moment when theater was

767.81.text:
flourishing, which was only for a few decades,
and then it was out again. There's a certain

772.64.text:
kind of luck. If you're the right person at
the right time in any one of the artistic

777.41.text:
genres.
Tyler:  Kanye West? Every album is different.

779.13.text:
He draws upon a lot of sources from the past.
Camille:  Oh my god. The bloat.

782.95.text:
Tyler:  Inspired by rap, rhythm and blues,
no?

785.05.text:
Camille:  What can I say?
Tyler:  I understand. Education, some questions

790.65.text:
about education. There's a new model school
called Minerva, where you take four years.

797.12.text:
You spend each of the four years in a foreign
country. One year in Buenos Aires, one in

802.50.text:
Istanbul, one in Bangalore, I think.
You work in small classes, but the classes

806.10.text:
are all online. There's no library. There's
no formal campus, per se. It's been around

810.89.text:
for about two years. What do you think? What's
your predictions?

813.21.text:
Camille:  I think the idea of sending young
people abroad is great. I think that's a proper

818.01.text:
use of the money that's going down the tubes
at the major universities right now. For parents

823.47.text:
to think, it would profit young people a lot
to be exposed to the world. Right now, our

830.63.text:
primary school education is absolutely appalling
in its lack of world history and world geography.

839.05.text:
I know because I get everyone in my classroom.
I'm lucky I teach at a kind of school where

844.22.text:
I'm getting students from a wide range of
preparation. There might be a couple private

848.79.text:
school people, but people from the inner city,
from good schools, from bad schools. I really

854.44.text:
have a very clear sense, after 40 years of
teaching, what's going on at the primary school

858.63.text:
level.
It is unbelievable how little they know. It

861.25.text:
is absolutely shocking how little they know.
This is a recipe for a disaster. I say yes,

866.73.text:
send them abroad. Fantastic idea.
This other thing of the online thing, I don't

870.03.text:
believe this online thing at all. I think
that you need a live person, and you need

876.14.text:
a live person who can talk extemporaneously
and respond to the moment. Not just people

882.58.text:
who are reading the same old damn lecture
over and over again. Also, the kind of formulaic

887.97.text:
teaching that goes on in the ivy league.
Also, the kind of teaching that goes on in

891.03.text:
the ivy league where there's a flattering.
There's these small seminar things.

896.43.text:
Tyler:  The A‑minus seminar, right?
Camille:  There's all this practice and learning

901.04.text:
how to talk in a slightly pretentious way
about things and impressing each other. So

905.47.text:
what? They're all packaging them for the bourgeoisie.
Tyler:  Send them to Brazil, right?

910.17.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  They're so proud of themselves

913.03.text:
as they produce all these clones, these polished,
bourgeois clones, witless, knowing nothing.

919.87.text:
Tyler:  Speaking of inspiring teachers, what's
your favorite Harold Bloom story that you

924.01.text:
can tell?
Camille:  My favorite? You mean personal

928.02.text:
Camille:  I don't know about favorite, but
if you want to know the story...

930.75.text:
Tyler:  The story, please.
Camille:  Here's the story. I never took

934.36.text:
a course with Harold Bloom. I was in graduate
school at Yale, and I just never took a course

939.54.text:
with him, so I didn't know him at all. I encountered
him...Uh‑oh, I shouldn't say this maybe.

950.26.text:
Let's say he would come according with a famous
poet, who was a friend of his.

960.08.text:
I would see him turning up at a doorway. "Hello,
hello, hello." I just knew him to say hello

966.90.text:
to him. Then, he heard what I was going to
be working on and that I was having trouble

970.96.text:
finding a dissertation director for a study
of androgyny in literature and art.

978.64.text:
It's hard to believe now because everything
is sex and gender everywhere, but at the time,

985.43.text:
no one was doing a dissertation on sex at
the Yale graduate school. It's hard to believe.

991.11.text:
He summoned me to his office. That's really
how we met. He said, "My dear, I am the only

997.95.text:
one who can direct that dissertation," and
I said, "OK." That was it.

1005.39.text:
He understood everything. He understood everything
I wanted to do with the book, and he understood

1010.48.text:
my ideas. He was a fantastic resource for
me in so far as he also supported me or gave

1018.91.text:
me confidence throughout all those decades
when I couldn't get it published. "Sexual

1023.21.text:
Personae" was rejected by seven publishers
and five agents.

1027.43.text:
By the time it was published, I was 43 years
old. I'm a great role model, it seems to me,

1035.00.text:
for people to just soldier through adversity
and rejection and just continue to develop

1042.13.text:
the craft. Eventually, hopefully, one will
see one's work in print.

1047.05.text:
Tyler:  What did he think of you and Sexual
Personae?

1050.14.text:
Camille:  Of course, he always said I gave
him great naches, which is like of a father

1059.35.text:
to a daughter. He and I agree about Freud.
We have a Freudian psychohistory and so on.

1067.59.text:
Tyler:  There's a segment of all of these
conversations in the middle. It's called underrated

1072.11.text:
or overrated. I mention something, and you
tell me if you think it's underrated or overrated

1076.28.text:
by our society.
Camille:  By our society or by me?

1080.16.text:
Tyler:  Your opinion relative to the society
opinion. Now, don't hold back on these. Tell

1085.69.text:
Tyler:  First one, economics.
Camille:  Economics as a field?

1090.93.text:
Tyler:  As a field. Overrated or underrated?
Camille:  Probably underrated.

1094.74.text:
Tyler:  Why?
Camille:  I don't know. I just think that

1099.25.text:
economists are figures of fun sometimes in
cartoons. I'm just judging by what I sense.

1105.74.text:
Tyler:  William Faulkner.
Camille:  He's totally gone, poor man. Actually,

1111.00.text:
I've been commenting on this recently to my
friends. I said, "You remember that period

1115.29.text:
when Faulkner was everywhere, and everyone
read him? He was just a baseline figure."

1120.77.text:
Thanks to Kate Millett and all these Philistine
feminist types in the early '70s, there was

1128.19.text:
a great sweeping away of many, many major
male figures in the history of literature

1133.84.text:
including Ernest Hemingway, D. H. Lawrence,
who had a huge influence on me.

1139.96.text:
If you are a resident of Mississippi, Faulkner
still lives and is vivid. I think, outside

1144.81.text:
of that, it's been years since I've heard
Faulkner mentioned.

1147.80.text:
Tyler:  You're saying underrated?
Camille:  I think he should be on the reading

1153.25.text:
list. I don't know. Perhaps he was overrated
in our time, but he certainly was a major

1157.36.text:
author and a major influence on American literature,
for heaven's sake. Young people aren't reading

1163.35.text:
him, and they aren't reading many of the great
authors.

1165.79.text:
Tyler:  Yoko Ono, overrated or underrated?
Camille:  Yoko Ono, don't start me on Yoko

1168.87.text:
Ono. One of my least favorite people in the
universe. Yes, I blame her for the breakup

1179.15.text:
Camille:  All that screeching yodeling that
went on. Oh my god, she's a horror. I gave

1186.06.text:
her her due in "Glittering Images," because
she was a very important figure in the development

1192.09.text:
of conceptual art. She really was very innovative
in the 1960s, but what a dreary, humorless

1201.20.text:
Tyler:  When I think of a lot of your books,
especially if I contrast you to Marxist criticism,

1208.11.text:
I think of your emphasis as being a lot of
metaphysics in a very exciting, big‑picture

1213.06.text:
way. Let's say we take a writer, very high
quality, but she moves very far from metaphysics.

1219.01.text:
She writes about small numbers of people in
rural Ontario, Alice Monroe.

1223.96.text:
Camille:  I don't read fiction. I don't read
contemporary fiction. I have absolutely zero

1229.07.text:
interest in contemporary fiction. The last
contemporary fiction I have any interest in

1233.82.text:
is "Auntie Mame," and I'm not kidding. I like
plays like "Tennessee Williams."

1238.39.text:
The fiction writers are off in another world.
They don't see the world as it exists now.

1244.57.text:
They don't use the language of the contemporary
world. Their English is utterly stale and

1250.27.text:
cloistered. I cannot read a page of contemporary
fiction, I'm sorry. Anything that's pre‑contemporary

1256.20.text:
fiction, I'm a great admirer of. Believe me,
these are the kind of books I'll open like

1263.04.text:
this and like that.
Tyler:  You're going to pass on "Harry Potter,"

1267.07.text:
too?
Camille:  Harry Potter, no, I don't. In fact,

1272.09.text:
I refused to write on Harry Potter for the
"Wall Street Journal" once. They said, "Who

1275.65.text:
should we ask next?" and they asked Harold
Bloom. Harold Bloom became known for it. He

1279.78.text:
got that because of me. Just like Norman Mailer
got to interview Madonna for the cover of

1284.78.text:
"Esquire" because Madonna said no to me.

1490.78.text:

1546.47.text:

1552.65.text:

1671.17.text:

1712.56.text:

That is why masculinity is constantly being

1721.40.text:

1728.16.text:

Camille:  They're completely bland. They

1755.89.text:

1759.13.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  They're eating their fruits which

1762.31.text:

1767.05.text:

I've been working for eight years on this,

2108.69.text:

2263.95.text:

forth, I hated it. It was early clashes that

These women, like Amelia Earhart, they did

[makes sounds] like this. These women were

Band. I adore the Stones. They hated the Stones.

Tyler:  More about you. Less about them.
[laughter]

2429.52.text:
[applause]
Camille:  Wait a minute. Then there was the

argument that I had. This is about Amelia

2446.79.text:

[laughter]
Tyler:  You can soon absorb, experience a

2549.61.text:
remarkable number, amount, and diversity of

to conversations at the shopping mall.

Camille:  I adore radio. The radio is fantastic,

2606.41.text:
talk shows, but also the sports shows. The
sports shows are the only place that you can

2611.72.text:
on radio actual working class voices calling

2618.03.text:
the game on Monday and what they would do
if they had $2 million, and who they would

2623.68.text:
hire."
It's fantastic. From my writer's voice is

2627.45.text:
actually very, rather than these novelists,
with their ricochet and lingo, my actual writing

2635.38.text:
voice is very influenced by the way English
is spoken today by people and often men on

2643.76.text:
radio. You get this high impact sound, you
see.

2648.10.text:
Tyler:  You once wrote, I quote, "My substitute
for LSD was Indian food," and by that, you

2655.76.text:
Tyler:  You stand by this.
Camille:  Yes, I've been in a rut on lamb

2658.21.text:
vindaloo.
Tyler:  A rut, tell us.

2659.21.text:
Camille:  It's a horrible rut.
Tyler:  It's not a horrible rut.

2661.58.text:
Camille:  No, it's a horrible...
Tyler:  It may be a rut.

2664.51.text:
Camille:  It's a 40‑year rut. Every time
I go to an Indian restaurant, I say, "Now,

2667.11.text:
I'm going to try something new." But, no,
I must go back to the lamb vindaloo.

2669.38.text:
All I know is it's like an ecstasy for me,
the lamb vindaloo.

2672.06.text:
Tyler:  Like De Quincey, tell us, what are
the effects of lamb vindaloo?

2674.91.text:
Camille:  What can I say? I attain nirvana.
[laughter]

2678.79.text:
Camille:  I don't know.
Tyler:  How would you describe your views

2684.24.text:
on astrology? A reader wrote to me, asked
me to ask you.

2686.92.text:
Camille:  Wait! Wait! You mentioned LSD,
can I say something else about that?

2690.11.text:
Tyler:  Sure, LSD, please.
Camille:  Now, LSD, I never took it, thank

2693.72.text:
God. I never took drugs. I didn't believe
it. I thought, "What is this untested thing?"

2698.14.text:
I thought, "A little wine, beer, all these
things have..."

2700.77.text:
Tyler:  Lamb vindaloo.
Camille:  "...thousands of years behind them,

2703.36.text:
right." I'm so glad I never took it. Everyone
around me was taking LSD. People who did take

2709.34.text:
LSD and survived will still say things like,
"Well, I'm really glad I did because I..."

2715.30.text:
Everyone says that I feel actually never attained
the level of accomplishment that they should

2720.01.text:
have in terms of whatever their vision had
been. I think LSD gave vision. It gave vision,

2725.09.text:
but then it deprived people of the ability
to translate that vision into material form

2730.20.text:
for the present and for posterity.
But I still remain very oriented toward the

2737.20.text:
LSD vision. I feel I took LSD because I have
the music. With "Bathing at Baxter's," Jefferson

2744.11.text:
Airplane, the first people to be using [makes
sound] like this." Distortions of the Byrds,

2749.67.text:
"Eight Miles High," I adore that song.
I feel I'm in that psychedelic [inaudible

2755.15.text:
49:45] . I have sometimes said that what I
do is psychedelic criticism because it is

2759.64.text:
metaphysical. It is visionary. I have a vision.
I have a vision that's bigger than society.

2763.22.text:
That's the problem with a Marxism approach.
I believe the Marxist approach is useful.

2769.85.text:
Arnold Hauser's one of the great...The social
history of art is one of the most influential

2774.81.text:
things on me. It's a Marxist perspective.
Indeed, my work is always very attentive to

2779.89.text:
the social context of anything. But what Marxism
lacks is that larger vision of the universe.

2785.87.text:
There are all kinds of questions and issues
about human life that Marxism has no answers

2790.30.text:
for. It doesn't even see it.
It doesn't see nature. What kind of a vision

2794.84.text:
doesn't see nature, could only see society?
This is what's happening. We have all these

2798.80.text:
graduates of the elite schools, whereas my
generation was all into a cosmic consciousness

2806.18.text:
and opening...We were influenced by Hinduism,
Buddhism, and all kinds of eastern...

2811.43.text:
I feel that is the true multiculturalism.
I've been arguing for that for 25 years. I've

2815.46.text:
been saying that if you want true multiculturalism,
you have to present world cultures, including

2822.01.text:
religion. Religion is extremely important,
the most complex systems human beings have

2828.00.text:
ever devised were the great religions of the
world.

2830.69.text:
Tyler:  Past Arnold Hauser, past Norman Brown,
who are the contemporary writers and thinkers

2835.90.text:
who influence you now who are writing serious
books on either the world cultures or anything

2843.02.text:
else?
Camille:  Is there anyone left writing serious

2846.96.text:
Camille:  I'm trying to think who has written
a serious book I'm interested in right now.

2850.62.text:
Listen, there's no one I would say, "Oh, so‑and‑so's
book is coming." What? They're dead. The people

2858.82.text:
who I admire are long dead.
Unfortunately, it's a terrible destruction.

2866.45.text:
My work looks very strange and idiosyncratic
because I'm alone. I'm alone and all the people

2872.81.text:
who should have been writing interesting,
quirky books, as I do, are dead or their brains

2880.52.text:
were destroyed by LSD.
It's one or the other. I knew so many, to

2886.46.text:
me, brilliant minds in graduate school and
early in my teaching career at Bennington

2891.59.text:
College, really brilliant minds. I had great
hopes for them and for what they would do.

2897.54.text:
Then they couldn't get anything done. For
whatever reason, they couldn't. They didn't

2904.03.text:
have the, I don't know what. They didn't have
the resilience to continue against obstacles.

2908.71.text:
When their work would get rejected, they would
become discouraged and would stop. Rejection

2914.38.text:
simply infuriates me. I'll say, "Well, I'll
have my revenge on you in the afterlife."

2919.08.text:
I'll be around, and you'll be dead. I don't
know. It's an Italian thing. What can I say?

2924.85.text:
Tyler:  This is Sexual Personae, your best
known book, which I recommend to everyone,

2928.82.text:
if you haven't already read it.
Camille:  It took 20 years.

2930.76.text:
Tyler:  Read all of it. My favorite chapter
is the Edmund Spenser chapter, by the way.

2933.76.text:
Camille:  Really? Why? How strange.
Tyler:  That brought Spenser to life for

2937.10.text:
Tyler:  I realized it was a wonderful book.
Camille:  Oh, my God.

2938.27.text:
Tyler:  I had no idea. I thought of it as
old and fusty and stuffy...

2941.52.text:
Camille:  Oh, yes.
Tyler:  ...and 100 percent because of you.

2943.61.text:
Camille:  We should tell them that "The Faerie
Queene" is quite forgotten now, but it had

2947.07.text:
enormous impact, Spenser's Faerie Queene,
on Shakespeare, and on the Romantic poets,

2952.57.text:
and so on, and so forth. "The Faerie Queene"
had been taught in this very moralistic way.

2955.60.text:
But in my chapter, I showed that it was entirely
a work of pornography, equal to the Marquis

2961.00.text:
Camille:  How interesting that you would
be drawn to that.

2965.64.text:
Tyler:  The cover image is Queen Nefertiti,
and the Neues Museum in Berlin. Recently in

2972.21.text:
the news, we've seen that someone has scanned
the bust...

2975.65.text:
Camille:  Oh, that's awesome.
Tyler:  ...and it will soon be possible using

2977.58.text:
3‑D printers to print out your own "copy"
of Nefertiti.

2980.95.text:
Camille:  [laughs]
Tyler:  How do you feel about this?

2987.39.text:
Camille:  To me, archaeology is one of my
master tropes. What can I say? The "Bust of

2994.74.text:
Nefertiti," discovered in 1912, and it's amazing.
We've known it for like a century. It's extraordinary,

3001.35.text:
isn't it, how it's become such a symbol of
art.

3006.50.text:
I should say that the push of countries like
Greece and Egypt to recover their masterpieces

3015.83.text:
from where they were taken and scattered around
the world, I think with what's been happening

3020.61.text:
with ISIS, and the demolition of Palmyra and
all kinds of things that have happened, my

3029.06.text:
attitude now is keep Nefertiti in Berlin,
please. Don't send it back to Cairo.

3034.80.text:
Tyler:  Of all the aesthetic judgments in
your writings, and you've covered a lot of

3039.69.text:
ground, but are there any where you really
fundamentally regret an earlier judgment and

3044.56.text:
have revised it? Not in a marginal way, which
happens all the time, but really just thought,

3048.69.text:
"Well, I was wrong about that?"
Camille:  Interesting. [laughs] I'm trying

3054.35.text:
to think. My early work, I'd worked on for
so long that it was like I had plenty of time

3059.91.text:
for second thoughts and third thoughts, and
hundredth thoughts, so no. I can't think of

3066.48.text:
anything offhand. Can I get back to you about
that?

3070.15.text:
Tyler:  If you could travel to one place
you haven't been, where would it be and why?

3075.83.text:
Camille:  I'm like [inaudible 55:10] . I
am not a great fan of traveling. I just feel

3084.96.text:
like it's become too onerous. No. I'm a mind
traveler.

3092.67.text:
Tyler:  What is your unrealized dream in
life?

3097.55.text:
Camille:  My unrealized dream, to meet Catherine
Deneuve, but I met her once. I ran into her,

3104.12.text:
smack‑ran into her once on 5th Ave in front
of Saks. I know this is kind of bizarre.

3109.05.text:
Tyler:  It's a realized dream?
Camille:  Yes, but it was odd. I pursued

3115.34.text:
her into the glove department and forced her
to sign my ticket envelope for the Fillmore

3120.40.text:
East, where I was seeing the Jefferson Airplane.
[laughter]

3123.82.text:
Camille:  To have a conversation with Catherine
Deneuve, shall we say. [laughs] A civilized

3129.01.text:
conversation.
Tyler:  On that topic, one of your books,

3131.84.text:
"The Birds," about the Alfred Hitchcock movie
‑‑ great book, one of my favorite movies.

3139.59.text:
Going back to that time, if you had the opportunity
to date either Suzanne Pleshette or Tippi

3145.68.text:
Tyler:  Date.
Camille:  I don't date. I'm just a mad nun...

3147.74.text:
Tyler:  Hypothetically.
Camille:  ...is all that I am.

3157.76.text:
Tyler:  Tea with Suzanne Pleshette or Tippi
Hedren.

3160.85.text:
Camille:  Tippi Hedren invited me to lunch
on Rodeo Drive after that. I was, I don't

3164.90.text:
know, giving some speech on Shakespeare at
the Los Angeles Public Library. She invited

3169.83.text:
to thank me for writing this and I met her.
She had a stack of 12 of these books, and

3173.94.text:
I signed them for her. She was the most elegant
and wonderful, warm woman.

3176.90.text:
I didn't have much time. She invited me to
go to the ranch and see all the animals and

3181.32.text:
the lions that she collected and so on.
Suzanne Pleshette, I think, was absolutely

3188.38.text:
underutilized by Hollywood. What an intelligent...she's
this nice, sharp character, she was. In fact,

3194.65.text:
I recently, in one of my "Salon" columns,
compared her to Lena Dunham is...oh.

3199.36.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Lena Dunham is the product of exactly

3203.05.text:
the same world. That whole affluent...our
entertainment world in Manhattan. I say, "Look

3209.68.text:
what's happened to culture." If you want to
see the difference between Suzanne Pleshette,

3215.00.text:
the sophisticated Suzanne Pleshette, and Lena
Dunham. You want to see the decline [laughs]

3220.76.text:
that we're in the middle of right now, there
it is.

3223.69.text:
Can I say a word about this?
Tyler:  Sure.

3226.90.text:
Camille:  I wrote this. The British Film
Institute asked me to write on a film and

3231.02.text:
I said, "How about The Birds?" and I did.
I wrote this book, and it was universally

3237.69.text:
panned by the film journals, which said about
it, "This book does nothing. This book does

3245.63.text:
nothing." By which they meant that it wasn't
poststructuralist, it wasn't postmodernist.

3250.45.text:
There wasn't a lot of theory. I wasn't citing
the male gaze, and etc., etc. All this book

3256.58.text:
does is go through the film The Birds from
beginning to end, scene by scene by scene,

3263.40.text:
and pays attention to the film itself.
Slowly it's made its way. Now here it is.

3271.27.text:
It was 1998 when that came out, and it's starting
to happen now. Routledge is a publisher that's

3276.79.text:
done nothing but this theory stuff. They're
starting to go, "Hmm. Maybe there was something

3281.21.text:
in her..." I'm hoping.
I'm just trying to inspire graduate students

3286.44.text:
to rebel against the fascism that forces theory
onto them before they expose themselves into

3294.53.text:
everything that's wonderful and imaginative
in the history of literature and art.

3300.39.text:
I believe in paying minute attention to the
actual work itself is the mission of criticism.

3307.24.text:
I am hopelessly old‑fashioned. Because that's
not what you're supposed to do. You're supposed

3310.78.text:
to mention Foucault 59 times in one paragraph,
etc.

3313.05.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  What a windbag that guy is, I'm

3317.31.text:
Camille:  Foucault is nothing. He's nothing.
[applause]

3320.07.text:
Camille:  Nothing. The reason why I know
he's nothing is because he was influenced

3325.26.text:
by...he pretends to be such a mastermind,
but in fact he's just a collection of influences

3330.74.text:
and one of the biggest influences on him was
Erving Goffman, of Philadelphia, who was the

3335.71.text:
great sociologist ‑‑ originally Canadian
‑‑ who wrote "The Presentation of Self

3339.56.text:
in Everyday Life." All the things that were
influence on me influenced Foucault.

3343.05.text:
You have all these people thinking Foucault
was some sort of innovative figure in the

3348.23.text:
history of modern sociology or intellect,
and he wasn't. It is a disease in these people.

3357.00.text:
Everywhere, every single university in the
United States, every single gender studies

3361.14.text:
department, they're impregnated with Foucault.
That's why we have graduates who know nothing.

3369.79.text:
Tyler:  Impregnated is an interesting word
to use.

3371.82.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Yes, it is. Yes. It is.

3374.46.text:
Tyler:  Do you like "Marnie," the Hitchcock
movie?

3377.10.text:
Camille:  Do I like Marnie? Certainly, I
like most of Marnie. Yeah.

3380.77.text:
Tyler:  But it goes askew in a way The Birds
doesn't.

3384.40.text:
Camille:  Yes. There are problems with it.
So much was toxic going on on the set between

3393.26.text:
Hitchcock and Tippi Hedren at that point,
and so on. But there are wonderful things

3397.50.text:
in Marnie.
Tyler:  If you were to take someone who had

3400.75.text:
read all or almost all of your work, and they
had a sense of you and read a lot of your

3405.51.text:
columns, watched some of your talks online,
whatever, and they get a picture of you, but

3411.38.text:
you wanted to tell them one thing about you
that maybe they wouldn't get from any of that

3416.19.text:
about what motivates you, what drives you,
what your life is actually like, what is...

3421.71.text:
Camille:  My life is completely mundane.
I'm a schoolmarm. That's all I am. I had the

3426.40.text:
wisdom, hello, having been raised Catholic,
that once I finally became known, at age 43,

3431.89.text:
I didn't change one thing about my life. Not
one thing. I didn't move to New York. I didn't

3436.08.text:
go chasing around. I didn't get a speakers'
bureau. All that stuff. I have a cousin who's

3445.27.text:
a nun, and I have all these bishops and priests
and sextons and so on in the family.

3452.23.text:
I just try to keep to reality. Because I know
that the basis of my work is the closeness

3458.69.text:
with which I live to ordinary life. I hate
the elites. I hate parties. I don't have any

3470.86.text:
book parties or anything like that. [groans]
[laughter]

3474.73.text:
Camille:  I think that people, they want
success and they want material advantages

3481.34.text:
and so on. Being a writer is just scut work.
Being a teacher, that's what Susan Sontag

3488.89.text:
also did wrong. Susan Sontag began in graduate
school. "Oh, it's so boring." She did a little

3494.47.text:
teaching and then went off and became a luminary.
She was a big luminary, a big giant dirigible

3502.15.text:
Camille:  ...floating above the continents.
"Here's Susan Sontag, the dirigible, woo...

3505.99.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Here she is." Nothing that she

3509.35.text:
said made any sense actually over time, eventually.
She loved to hold court at parties. It's notorious.

3517.52.text:
People who remember her, "She was so brilliant.
I saw her at this dinner party. Everyone was

3521.67.text:
in awe."
People who go to dinner parties to impress

3525.16.text:
other people, it is such BS. Susan Sontag
over time, her work got less and less meaningful,

3530.24.text:
even though people worship at the shrine of
Sontag. You try to quote her on anything.

3534.93.text:
What can you quote her on? There's nothing
important. The one thing you can quote her

3540.98.text:
Camille:  Quote a sentence from Susan Sontag,
a great sentence. You can't. The only sentence

3546.30.text:
was the one she regretted, "The white race
is the cancer of history." That's the one

3550.06.text:
she retracted finally when she got cancer.
Remember? She realized how horrible that was.

3552.87.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Now she realized. "Now I realize

3556.31.text:
I shouldn't have said that." That's the only
thing that you can quote her on. She's not

3561.98.text:
quotable, because there's all this sleight
of hand that she's doing. She's taking material

3566.98.text:
that she borrows from others, or places that
she's been personally at a time when downtown

3571.92.text:
New York was very exciting, so basically it
was a kind of transcription of her everyday

3576.01.text:
life.
I think the best thing she did probably was

3578.51.text:
for me, she wrote a very witty thing, "The
Imagination of Disaster." I like that essay

3582.89.text:
a lot, which is all about the horror films
of the 1950s. I thought if she only had stayed

3586.98.text:
like that, unpretentious and really engaging
with actual materials.

3594.63.text:
But Susan Sontag, basically her life became
going from lecture to lecture, being hailed

3601.89.text:
as the Great One, and being so detached from
ordinary life. Whereas, when you're a teacher,

3607.52.text:
like a classroom teacher, as I've been for
40 years, the kids have no idea that I write

3616.37.text:
books. Now and then, someone's father will
say, "She writes books," and they'll come

3623.80.text:
and say, "My father is a fan of yours." "Oh,
really? That's so nice," I'll say.

3630.90.text:
Anyway, the point is all these professors
at Harvard, and Princeton, and Yale, they

3636.17.text:
have the graduate students are paying court
to them, because they need letters of recommendations.

3639.49.text:
Hello, they want something from you. They're
so grand and so on.

3643.49.text:
I go in, and it's like, "We need more chairs."
"What's wrong?" "The curtain is wrong." I'm

3651.34.text:
always in touch with the janitors, infrastructure,
condition of the buildings. I deal with everyday

3657.82.text:
life. I'm not treated like a queen. I'm just
like an ordinary schoolmarm working like a

3666.83.text:
horse, pulling the plow.
I think that's a really good idea for writers

3674.44.text:
is to have a job where you're dealing with
constant frustrations, and problems, and so

3679.54.text:
on. I think that's really good for you.
Tyler:  Like Herman Melville, right?

3681.54.text:
Camille:  Yes, yes.
Tyler:  Hunting whales is not easy.

3683.25.text:
Camille:  Or Wallace Stevens. He kept going
to the office, the insurance company, every

3687.97.text:
day.
Tyler:  My last question before they get

3691.34.text:
to ask you, but I know there are many people
in this audience, or at least some, who are

3695.60.text:
considering some kind of life or career in
the world of ideas. If you were to offer them

3701.27.text:
a piece of advice based on your years struggling
with the infrastructure, and the number of

3706.35.text:
chairs, and whatever else, what would that
be?

3708.95.text:
Camille:  Get a job. Have a job. Again, that's
the real job. Every time you have frustrations

3716.21.text:
with the real job, you say, "This is good."
This is good, because this is reality. This

3721.30.text:
is reality as everybody lives it. This thing
of withdrawing from the world to be a writer,

3726.87.text:
I think, is a terrible mistake.
Number one thing is constantly observing.

3732.12.text:
My whole life, I'm constantly jotting things
down. Constantly. Just jot, jot, jot, jot.

3737.38.text:
I'll have an idea. I'm cooking, and I have
an idea, "Whoa, whoa." I have a lot of pieces

3744.30.text:
of paper with tomato sauce or whatever. I
transfer these to cards or I transfer them

3749.36.text:
to notes.
I'm just constantly open. Everything's on

3755.62.text:
all the time. I never say, "This is important.
This is not important." That's why I got into

3762.09.text:
popular culture at a time when popular culture
was...

3764.89.text:
In fact, there's absolutely no doubt that
at Yale graduate school, I lost a huge credibility

3771.42.text:
with the professors because of my endorsement
of not only film but Hollywood. Hollywood

3777.65.text:
was considered crass entertainment and so
on. Now, the media studies came in very strongly

3784.48.text:
after that, although highly theoretical. Not
the way I teach media studies.

3788.57.text:
I also believe in following your own instincts
and intuition, like there's something meaningful

3795.32.text:
here. You don't know what it is, but you just
keep it on the back burner. That's basically

3802.02.text:
how I work is this, the constant observation.
Also, I try to tell my students, they never

3809.77.text:
get the message really, but what I try to
say to them is nothing is boring. Nothing

3816.05.text:
is boring. If you're bored, you're boring.
[laughter]

3821.89.text:
Camille:  Wherever you are, it's exhausting.
It's frustrating. I don't know what. The plane

3829.78.text:
has been canceled and whatever. After you
get over your fury, you realize what opportunity

3837.36.text:
is there here to absorb something more from
this experience, from observing other people

3842.12.text:
or whatever it is.
I think there's really no experience that

3844.98.text:
you can have that there's not something in
there that eventually you can't use as a part

3850.22.text:
of your developing system.
Another thing I have to say, anyone interested

3855.74.text:
in ideas, do not read any of the current books
like Pierre Bourdieu and all that stuff. Oh

3862.42.text:
my god, it's so incomplete. It's really boring.
I believe in the library. The library is my

3867.77.text:
shrine. It was my shrine when I was researching
Amelia Earhart. When I got to Yale, Sterling

3873.16.text:
Library was my shrine. I ransacked that building,
oh my god.

3878.21.text:
That's the thing, is that I've learned more
from the old commentators. James George Frazer,

3885.74.text:
"The Golden Bough," which was considered completely
gone but had a huge impact on "The Wasteland"

3889.34.text:
and other works of modernism. I've learned
a great deal from the commentators of the

3896.57.text:
past, the historians of the past.
Now, when I did "Glittering Images," the actual

3904.17.text:
nullity of current scholarship became very
exposed to me. Of course, I already knew about

3909.59.text:
it, but I really got objective proof of it.
There's 29 chapters in it. Each artwork that

3919.28.text:
I chose, I did a full research of what had
been said about that particular artwork, so

3923.79.text:
I began chronologically.
I would work, if it was an older work from

3926.46.text:
the late 19th century, moving through the
decades to the present. There, oh my god,

3933.76.text:
could you see it, could you see the fall in
the quality of scholarship in our time from

3941.03.text:
the 1980s on. I would move from these incredibly
erudite and wonderful sentences, beautiful

3950.48.text:
stylus about art, late 19th century moving
into the 20th century.

3955.43.text:
Still solid into about the '60s. In the '70s,
kind of holding there. All of a sudden comes

3962.18.text:
the '80s, '90s, 20s. All these people, pygmies.
Pygmies, the people at the elite schools.

3969.09.text:
Let me say, the big art survey courses are
being dismantled. Hello? It used to be you

3977.96.text:
had a two‑semester course. It would begin
with cave art and move, in two semesters,

3984.26.text:
down to modernism.
Magnificent structure, now abandoned wholesale

3989.51.text:
except when students have protested, like
at Smith. My sister is a graduate of Smith,

3994.47.text:
and was part of the protest that got the survey
restored.

4001.45.text:
Graduate students in art history and art historians
no longer have the ability to teach the big

4006.53.text:
picture, because all narratives are regarded
as fictional now and imperialistic fictions.

4011.54.text:
The entire story of art is not possible, and
therefore, people know nothing.

4016.32.text:
Tyler:  I need to give them the chance to
ask you questions, but thank you for a fascinating

4023.77.text:
Camille:  Thank you. [laughs]
Tyler:  We have two mics. I will alternate

4031.07.text:
mics. These are questions. They are not lengthy
statements. Go to the microphone so you will

4032.07.text:
be picked up by the taping. Also, if you go
on, I will cut you off and simply shorten

4033.07.text:
your question. We start here. Feel free to
identify yourself if you would like.

4035.38.text:
Shanna Davidson:  Hi, my name is Shanna Davidson.
Camille:  Hello.

4038.10.text:
Shanna:  You mentioned Smith. I saw you speak
at Smith, or Mount Holyoke, in 1993. It was

4045.82.text:
fascinating to compare that to this, because
there was a great deal of booing and hissing

4050.80.text:
at Smith. It was eye‑opening to me, being
steeped in this ‑‑ I am going to wrap

4060.68.text:
up ‑‑ the hegemony of the patriarchy and
how we must even dress like men.

4067.00.text:
You saying something to the effect of, "I
teach in a skirt, because I have more control

4072.27.text:
over the classroom that way."
Camille:  Actually, I don't remember teaching

4075.87.text:
in a skirt, but go ahead.
Shanna:  In any case, I remember something

4079.58.text:
to that effect. The question is, do you think
that feminism has evolved beyond that, or

4086.23.text:
is it just sort of running that same record
dry?

4089.73.text:
Camille:  It's really shocking. When I arrived
at Smith's, they had papered the walkway,

4096.77.text:
in fact, as people walked in with all these
hostile and uncomprehending things. People

4102.32.text:
had no idea what my real ideas were. The whole
PC thing was escalating out of control at

4110.21.text:
that point.
It's really shocking. Here is a woman, a middle‑aged

4116.14.text:
woman at that point, I'm in my 40s, who had
spent 20 years writing a book that had been

4121.96.text:
rejected, and finally was published by EL
Press. A book on the whole history of the

4126.18.text:
Western civilization, and this is the treatment
that I got at Smith College?

4130.68.text:
This is one of the bastions of the Seven Sisters,
one of the most noble names in the history

4139.93.text:
of modern women's education. That just shows
you how ideology really is very distorting.

4146.92.text:
Feminism is going through phases. I call myself
a feminist, absolutely. I simply belong to

4153.37.text:
a dissident wing of feminism, and I think
that the error made by all these people was

4158.03.text:
not to understand that my wing of feminism
had been suppressed and silenced at that point

4162.62.text:
for 25 years.
Eventually, we won in the '90s, the pro‑sex

4166.84.text:
wing of feminism, thanks to Madonna, who wasn't
a feminist. But because of Madonna's foregrounding

4172.45.text:
of sexual themes and so on, it allowed us
to break through the over‑control by the

4180.07.text:
Tyler:  I'll take another question, but you'll
still get to say more.

4184.53.text:
Camille:  The problem is right now that a
whole younger generation has risen up, and

4192.30.text:
it's now Steinem has returned. She's like
a bad penny. She's back again.

4195.89.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  I feel like I'm back to square

4201.55.text:
Tyler:  Next question, here.
Camille:  I'm sorry we can't go on.

4205.80.text:
Audience Member:  Hi, thanks for coming.
You mentioned your incident with Catherine

4209.29.text:
Deneuve, and you also talked about that in
1995 and Playboy following her, and also having

4217.95.text:
Audience Member:  At the same time earlier
this year, when David Bowie passed away, and

4222.04.text:
you mentioned how he had reached out to you
and wanted to meet you, you talked about how

4225.39.text:
you weren't sure you would have wanted to,
because you have to keep a respectful distance

4228.56.text:
from an artist of that towering stature.
You also mentioned in that interview that

4234.61.text:
obsession and genius are pretty much the same
thing, so where would you draw the line between...Say

4239.54.text:
you have an opportunity to meet someone who's
very important to you, or contrive a meeting,

4244.51.text:
or just seek them out. Where do you draw the
line between the obsession, and I mean the

4249.07.text:
[inaudible 74:56] kind of obsession, not the
Roy Hinkley kind...

4254.46.text:
distance? Do you stifle creativity with respect
for who this person is and their privacy?

4261.70.text:
Camille:  I personally have never had this
great desire, necessarily, to meet the figures

4268.02.text:
that I most admire in the arts, because I
understand that what they represent onscreen

4274.45.text:
is something that is an artificial construction.
It's not the reality.

4279.49.text:
I've been working in art schools also my entire
career, so I know. I have dancers in my class.

4285.10.text:
I have actors in my class, and I couldn't
understand the difference between the fallible

4290.91.text:
real self, the mundane real self, and the
artistic self suddenly emerges within what

4297.42.text:
I call the temenos, which is the sacred precinct
that I regard as art.

4302.80.text:
Therefore, when I encountered Catherine Deneuve
by accident that day, and I was at the peak

4308.50.text:
of my obsession with her, it really almost
ruined my interest in her, because it's like,

4314.46.text:
"Oh, my god." It's not the real Catherine
Deneuve [laughs] that I was so intent on.

4320.33.text:
It was this magical creation that is a result
of her talent, but also of the director's

4327.47.text:
own magical skills, and so on.
Oh, yes, Elizabeth Taylor, I have 599 pictures,

4333.27.text:
yes. People often say what's odd about that
is not the number, but that I had counted

4338.99.text:
Camille:  She represented to me everything,
the pure sexuality that had been repressed

4345.23.text:
during the Doris Day 1950s and early '60s.
Butterfield A still remains for me a great

4352.63.text:
pagan exhibition. Here is Elizabeth Taylor
as a high class call girl. Oh, my god, and

4360.19.text:
I had Jeanne Moreau and Monica Vitti, and
[inaudible 76:50] , and [inaudible 76:53].

4366.66.text:
There were so many phenomenal images that
I was inundated with when I was in high school

4372.79.text:
and college, and what do these kids have today?
Taylor Swift? Oh, my god. She is such a fake.

4380.91.text:
She poses in things that she imagines are
sexy and sultry, and it's so fake. Awful,

4385.94.text:
awful, awful. At least Rihanna, who's on dope
most of the time, and that's why she looks

4391.80.text:
Camille:  Rihanna's Instagrams are, to me,
like a work of art. That's the only thing

4395.47.text:
I'm following right now, I have to say, that's
of equal importance, is Rihanna floating from

4399.87.text:
one nightclub to another, and yet some other
fashionable thing, but back to your question.

4407.05.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Wait, did I answer? I don't know

4410.69.text:
if I answered the question.
Audience Member:  I'm not sure, either.

4419.17.text:
Camille:  Oh, David Bowie. I wrote this essay
called "Theater or Gender." David Bowie at

4424.46.text:
the climax of the sexual revolution, I wrote
it for the Victoria and Albert exhibition

4429.52.text:
catalog for the costume show that they did
that is now touring the world, and I consider

4433.87.text:
it one of my most important pieces, but it's
in the catalog.

4437.28.text:
I want to get into my next essay collection,
but with Bowie, see, Bowie is different than

4442.46.text:
Deneuve. Bowie is truly like a creative artist,
whereas Deneuve and Taylor are performers

4449.73.text:
in other people's fictions. But Bowie was
truly a master creator of a level that just

4457.39.text:
is staggering.
When I did the research for that essay, I

4462.56.text:
knocked out all over again at the enormity
of what he achieved, and also at how little

4469.12.text:
has been acknowledged, his deep knowledge
of the visual arts, and how he had been influenced

4473.70.text:
by that. I found all kinds of little details
that showed his deep knowledge, his erudition

4478.33.text:
about that.
It appears to be that he did tell the V&A

4482.35.text:
to invite...That time, people don't know.
What you're talking about is where...It was

4488.94.text:
earlier in the 1990s, and a message came to
my publisher saying ‑‑ and it was conveyed

4494.95.text:
to me by the publicist and my publisher ‑‑ saying,
"David Bowie wants your phone number," and

4501.35.text:
Camille:  I said, "That's ridiculous. Oh,
boy. It's just some fan trying to get it."

4505.83.text:
They said, "David Bowie they claimed really
wants your phone number." I said, "Is that

4510.14.text:
the way David Bowie gets in touch with you
when he wants your phone number?" I laughed,

4513.64.text:
and I didn't believe it. It was all so shadowy.
Only now, only after I did the research for

4521.87.text:
this Victoria and Albert thing, did I realize
that the reason it was so strange was that

4526.10.text:
he had fired his entire staff. He had fired
his management. He had fired his company,

4531.48.text:
and dealing with the record companies and
so on after Berlin, and that he only dealt

4535.70.text:
with the world via friends. That's what was
so strange about it. It was strange. I made

4543.29.text:
a mistake.
What he wanted was he wanted to use an excerpt

4546.16.text:
from Sexual Persona on a record album in one
of his lyrics. I'm like, "Oh, my god." It's

4551.77.text:
very embarrassing that that happened, but
that's OK. I think there should be a distance,

4559.56.text:
or a sense of respect and reserve, with greater
artists.

4562.23.text:
Tyler:  Next question?
Kelly Ferguson:  Hi. I'm Kelly Ferguson.

4566.11.text:
Camille:  Hi.
Kelly:  I'm a master's economics student

4568.78.text:
here at George Mason, and I'm told today is
Equal Pay Day, so that makes the question

4572.45.text:
I want to ask you about pay disparity even
more relevant, I guess.

4575.58.text:
I've been thinking about it a lot, and it
seems to me that it boils down to a problem

4579.62.text:
of culture, to the extent that, for example,
Mark Zuckerberg publicizing taking paternity

4585.97.text:
leave does more to alleviate the pay disparity
problem that we have than either companies

4592.65.text:
or governments setting a policy.
Because to the extent that the demand for

4597.47.text:
flexibility, to have children and care for
children is only used by women, it's going

4602.67.text:
to hurt us on the margin when it comes to
pay. Since you're such a great and incisive

4607.21.text:
social critic, I just wanted to get your thoughts
on that.

4611.61.text:
Camille:  First of all, I think the way that
my own party, the Democratic party, is using

4617.40.text:
this rubric of equal pay for women as if this
has not been a matter of law ever since the

4624.76.text:
presidency of JFK, for heaven sakes.
There may be cases of outrageous disparity

4632.87.text:
in pay for doing the same work. Now and then,
they'll find something like in a hospital,

4639.91.text:
a woman doctor, a veteran doctor who's not
being paid the same level. But it's rare when

4645.57.text:
these actual cases do surface.
There's all this propaganda being pumped out

4654.43.text:
about this issue, when in fact, women are
not...If women are earning 72 cents or 75

4660.99.text:
cents on the dollar, it's not for the same
job. This is the lie that's being told. Women

4669.34.text:
doing the same job as a man are not being
paid 75 cents for something that the man is

4673.70.text:
being paid a dollar.
What it is, is overall, the averages of women,

4677.71.text:
of their own volition, for whatever reasons,
are taking jobs that have more flexibility

4685.15.text:
as opposed to the around‑the‑clock, seven
days a week, night thing.

4689.83.text:
For example, women tend to shy away from sales
jobs where they're on the road a lot, and

4698.38.text:
that is where a lot of men have very high
earnings. Women are making choices, and they

4705.19.text:
would prefer to be closer to their children,
so yes. These disparities are ultimately based

4710.63.text:
in biological differences.
Susan Faludi and these other feminists of

4716.68.text:
the Steinem kind of credo have one answer.
Men must do more. That's their answer. Men

4725.66.text:
must do more. Susan Faludi has never had a
child, so has absolutely no idea.

4733.35.text:
What I feel is that there is a tie. There
is an ineffable, indefinable biological tie

4748.19.text:
between a child and the mother in whose body
the child has developed into a full being,

4756.27.text:
and that there are all kinds of impulses and
instincts that women may have of protectiveness

4762.79.text:
toward their biologically born children.
To politicize the thing, and to assume that

4772.77.text:
a woman bearing a child is like an automaton,
"Yes, here is the baby. Here, to my husband,

4778.61.text:
you are equally fit to be able to nurture
this three month‑old child."

4786.48.text:
As a child gets a little older and turns into
a real human being with a personality and

4792.30.text:
so on, it's not so dependent, then is when
men can do more. I believe personally, from

4799.72.text:
my observation of human life, that there is
something going on. An infant doesn't want

4806.45.text:
the father, hello.
The infant wants the mother. You want the

4810.84.text:
nice, cushy...The smell is the mother. "Who
is this person coming closer? Go away." Freud

4817.06.text:
talked about that. This distraction comes
in, the father. "Get out." Remember?

4822.64.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  This is why Freud said every child

4825.30.text:
wants to kill the father and marry the mother.
They don't want men, and men don't know what

4831.82.text:
to do. Men are clumsy, and they have the big
hands and so on.

4835.76.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  What I have seen from my own observation

4838.77.text:
is that women...Because I have a child who
I adopted from my former partner and so on.

4846.90.text:
What I have seen is the world of the moms.
I have seen the world of the moms from the

4851.68.text:
inside, and what I see is that the minute
our children are born, it's the woman who

4861.56.text:
biologically, I believe, has the master strategist
mind.

4865.63.text:
She is the generalissimo of the household.
The man, her husband, who was once her equal,

4870.91.text:
shrinks down to merely one counter.
[laughter]

4873.70.text:
Camille:  Becomes one. It is she who issues
the master plan for the week. He is hopeless.

4880.17.text:
She has the multiple levels. She assigns.
She knows what, and she's the one who makes

4884.34.text:
the schedule and so on, and the good father
is the one who says, "OK, yes, I will do.

4888.12.text:
OK, give me the plan, give me the sheet,"
and so forth.

4890.15.text:
To ask men to do more, seems to me to ask
them to do something that they are not biologically

4895.92.text:
Tyler:  Our next question is from a man.
Camille:  Oh, sorry. That was so interesting,

4898.00.text:
I wanted to go on, but it's all right.
[laughter]

4901.42.text:
Tyler:  Yes.
Audience Member:  I'd just like to preface

4904.17.text:
my question by saying that as a whirlwind,
Jobe's God has nothing on you.

4911.43.text:
Audience Member:  My question is do you ever
have any concern that modern literature and

4916.35.text:
eventually all the classics will have to be
rewritten so that in order to be understood,

4922.35.text:
every fifth word will have to be the word
"like"?

4926.41.text:
[laughter]
Camille:  Unfortunately, the sense of language

4930.88.text:
in general, or just a respect for language
or interest in language is degenerating. I'm

4936.95.text:
someone who used to write down, always, I'd
write down any word I don't know in what I'm

4944.12.text:
reading. I would make lists, and I would study
the dictionary and etymologies, and now, young

4949.57.text:
people have no concern for language, per se.
The way they communicate with each other and

4954.47.text:
the email format now in text is very truncated,
and it's why the writing on the Web has also

4962.51.text:
degenerated horribly. The writing for blogs
is blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, and

4966.32.text:
no one has...
It used to be with newspapers and magazines,

4968.63.text:
there was a space limit, and that imposed
a real kind of format. It forced you to condense,

4976.12.text:
and it gave a crispness to language. We're
in a period now, I'm afraid that the ear for

4982.62.text:
language is degenerating.
Tyler:  One last question, very quickly.

4985.56.text: Camille:  Oh, the last one? Oh, no.

4986.84.text:
Audience Member:  I'll try to be quick. In
my view, feminists have made a lot of progress

4991.03.text:
in the Western world in the last century,
and I'm curious to know if you think we're

4996.47.text:
close to basically achieving the goals that
were set out, or if the feminists will ever

5003.01.text:
feel like the fact that more women go to college
these days, for example, is a symbol of progress,

5009.39.text:
or that they'll never feel like the job has
been done?

5012.59.text:
Tyler:  You have one minute, 30 seconds to
answer this question.

5014.72.text:
Camille:  Oh, no. I'm an equal opportunity
feminist, by which I believe that all obstacles

5018.57.text:
to women's advance in the political and professional
realms should be removed.

5024.03.text:
What I'm also saying is that there are huge
areas of human life that are not political

5028.17.text:
that have to do with our private spiritual
nature, and that is a place where legislation

5032.99.text:
will always be helpless and hopeless, and
indeed, intrusive, so I think that feminism's

5040.32.text:
made enormous gains in terms of there was
a time that women were totally dependent on

5049.22.text:
father, on husband, on brother, for their
survival.

5053.06.text:
Now, women can be self‑supporting, can live
totally on their own. It's part of this whole

5059.04.text:
Western world powered by capitalism that our
university curricula are now habitually always

5067.40.text:
demeaning. Capitalism made women's emancipation
possible.

5073.64.text:
I think that the problem right now is that
young women have been taught that to somehow

5083.30.text:
identify their own sense of personal unhappiness
with men, and men are responsible for our

5088.29.text:
unhappiness, when in fact, part of the issue
is that we have lived as a species for tens

5094.70.text:
of thousands of year, where mating occurred
early, where you left your parents' house,

5103.93.text:
and had your own household, and your own children.
Juliet, in Romeo and Juliet, is 13 going on

5110.66.text:
14, and already, she's ready for marriage.
In this life, we have a very long, an unnaturally

5115.86.text:
long period here, before women can attain
some sense of who they are as women. I think

5123.40.text:
that that is...
It's not men. It's not the patriarchy, and

5126.48.text:
it's ultimately not a feminist issue. It has
something to do with this very mechanical

5131.77.text:
system of the modern technological, professional
world that has emerged to replace the agrarian

5138.54.text:
period, when there were multi generations
living with each other, and women had a natural

5144.00.text:
sense of solidarity, being all together.
There was the world of women, and the world

5148.84.text:
of men, once. They didn't have that much to
do with each other once. All the problems

5153.77.text:
have happened since we started having to deal
with each other.

5155.21.text:
[laughter]
Tyler:  Just to close, Steven Pinker will

5157.50.text:
be coming in October 24th. This summer, we'll
have Cass Sunstein, not yet scheduled. There

5162.76.text:
are books for sale outside, yes? No. Camille,
we thank you heartily, so, so much.
